paragraph: CHAPTER X. TAKING REFUGE.
tokens: chapter taking refuge

paragraph: For a minute or two I seemed to feel nothing; then there came over me a sort of shiver, partly of cold, for it _was_ very cold, partly of misery. I roused myself, however. With the remembrance of that other evening had come to me also the knowledge of where I was. Only a few yards down the sloping street on the left-hand side came a wide stretch of pavement, and there, in a kind of angle, stood a double door, open on both sides, leading into a small outer hall, from which again another door, glazed at the top, was the entrance to Cranston's show-rooms.
tokens: minute seem feel come sort shiver cold cold misery rouse remembrance other evening come knowledge few yard slope street left hand side come wide stretch pavement kind angle stand double door open side lead small outer hall door glaze top entrance show room

paragraph: I remembered it all perfectly. Just beyond the inner entrance stood the two carved lions that Haddie and I admired so much. I wished I could see them again, and--yes--a flash of joy went through me at the thought--I could get Mrs. Selwood's address quite as well from old Mr. Cranston as from the big grocer!
tokens: remember inner entrance stand carve lion admire wish see flash joy go thought get address old big grocer

paragraph: As soon as the idea struck me I hurried on, seeming to gain fresh strength and energy. It was almost dark, but a gas-lamp was burning dimly above the lintel, and inside, on the glass of the inner door, were the large gilt letters "Cranston and Co."
tokens: idea strike hurry seem gain fresh strength energy dark gas lamp burn lintel glass inner door large gilt letter

paragraph: I ran up the two or three broad shallow steps and pushed open the door, which was a swing one. It was nearly time for closing, but that I did not know. There was no one to be seen inside, not, at least, in the first room, and the door made no noise. But there stood the dear lions--I could not see them very clearly, for the place was not brightly lighted, but I crept up to them, and stroked softly the one nearest me. They seemed like real friends.
tokens: run broad shallow step push open door swing one time closing know be see least first room door make noise stand dear lion see place light creep stroke one seem real friend

paragraph: I had not courage to go into the other show-room, and all was so perfectly still that I could scarcely think any one was there. I thought I would wait a few minutes in hopes of some one coming out, of whom I could inquire if I could see Mr. Cranston. And I was now beginning to feel so tired--so very tired, and so cold.
tokens: have courage go other show room think one think wait few minute hope one come inquire see begin feel tired tired cold

paragraph: In here, though I did not see any fire, it felt ever so much warmer than outside. There was no chair or stool, but I found a seat for myself on the stand of the farther-in lion--each of them had a heavy wooden stand. It seemed very comfortable, and I soon found that by moving on a little I could get a nice rest for my head against the lion's body. A strange pleasant sense of protection and comfort came over me.
tokens: see fire feel warm be chair stool find seat stand far lion have heavy wooden stand seem comfortable find move little get nice rest head lion body strange pleasant sense protection comfort come

paragraph: "How glad I am I came in here," I said to myself. "I don't mind if I have to wait a good while. It is so cosy and warm."
tokens: glad come say mind have wait good while cosy warm

paragraph: I no longer made any plans. I knew I wanted to ask for Mrs. Selwood's address, but that was all I thought of. What I should do when I had got it I did not know; where I should go for the night, for it was now quite dark, I did not trouble about in the least. I think I must have been very much in the condition I have heard described, of travellers lost in the snow--the overpowering wish to stay where I was and rest, was all I was conscious of. I did not think of going to sleep. I did not know I was sleepy.
tokens: make plan know want ask address think do get know go night dark trouble least think condition hear describe traveller lose snow overpowering wish stay rest conscious think go sleep know sleepy

paragraph: And for some time I knew nothing.
tokens: time know

paragraph: The first thing that caught my attention was a very low murmur--so low that it might have been merely a breath of air playing in the keyhole; I seemed to have been hearing it for some time before it took shape, as it were, and grew into a softly-whispering voice, gradually gathering into words.
tokens: first thing catch attention low murmur low breath air play keyhole seem hear time take shape grow whisper voice gather word

paragraph: "Poor little girl; so she has come at last. Well, as you say, brother, we have been expecting her for a good while, have we not?"
tokens: poor little girl come last say brother expect good while

paragraph: "Yes, indeed, but speak softly. It would be a pity to awake her. And what we have to do can be done just as well while she sleeps."
tokens: speak pity awake have do do sleep

paragraph: "I don't agree with you," said the first speaker. "I should much prefer her being awake. She would enjoy the ride, and she is an intelligent child and would profit by our conversation."
tokens: agree say first speaker prefer awake enjoy ride intelligent child profit conversation

paragraph: "As you like," replied number two. "I must be off to fetch the boy. She will perhaps be awake by the time I return."
tokens: like reply number fetch boy awake time return

paragraph: And then--just as I was on the point of starting up and telling them I _was_ awake--came a sound of stamping and rustling, and a sort of whirr and a breath of cold air, which told me the swing door had been opened. And when I sat straight up and looked about me, lo and behold, there was only one lion to be seen--the stand of his brother was empty!
tokens: point start tell come sound stamp rustling sort whirr breath cold air tell swing door open sit look be lion see stand brother empty

paragraph: "I--please I _am_ awake," I said rather timidly. "It was me you were talking about, wasn't it?"
tokens: awake say talk

paragraph: "_I_--'it was _I_'--the verb to be takes the same case after it as before it," was the reply, much to my surprise and rather to my disgust. Who would have thought that the carved lions bothered about grammar!
tokens: verb take same case reply much surprise disgust think carve lion bother grammar

paragraph: "It was I, then," I repeated meekly. I did not want to give any offence to my new friend. "Please--I heard you saying something--something about going a ride. And where has the--the other Mr. Lion gone? I heard about--a boy."
tokens: repeat want give offence new friend hear say go ride other gone hear boy

paragraph: "You heard correctly," my lion replied, and I knew somehow that he was smiling, or whatever lions do that matches smiling. "My brother has gone to fetch _your_ brother--we planned it all some time ago--we shall meet on the sea-shore and travel together. But we should be starting. Can you climb up on to my back?"
tokens: hear lion reply know smile lion do match smile brother go fetch _your_ brother plan time meet sea shore travel start climb back

paragraph: "Oh yes," I said quite calmly, as if there was nothing the least out of the common in all this, "I'm sure I can."
tokens: say be least common sure

paragraph: "Catch hold of my mane," said the lion; "don't mind tugging, it won't hurt," and--not to my surprise, for nothing surprised me--I felt my hands full of soft silky hair, as the lion shook down his long wavy mane to help my ascent.
tokens: catch hold mane say lion mind tug hurt surprise surprise feel hand full soft silky hair lion shake long wavy mane help ascent

paragraph: Nothing was easier. In another moment I was cosily settled on his back, which felt deliciously comfortable, and the mane seemed to tuck itself round me like a fleecy rug.
tokens: easy moment settle back feel comfortable mane seem tuck fleecy rug

paragraph: "Shut your eyes," said my conductor or steed, I don't know which to call him; "go to sleep if you like. I'll wake you when we meet the others."
tokens: shut eye say conductor steed know call go sleep like wake meet other

paragraph: "Thank you," I said, feeling too content and comfortable to disagree with anything he said.
tokens: thank say feel content comfortable disagree say

paragraph: Then came a feeling of being raised up, a breath of colder air, which seemed to grow warm again almost immediately, and I knew nothing more till I heard the words, "Here they are."
tokens: come feeling raise breath cold air seem grow warm know more hear word

paragraph: I opened my eyes and looked about me. It was night--overhead in the deep blue sky innumerable stars were sparkling, and down below at our feet I heard the lap-lap of rippling waves. A dark, half-shadowy figure stood at my right hand, and as I saw it more clearly I distinguished the form of the other lion, with--yes, there was some one sitting on his back.
tokens: open eye look night overhead deep blue sky innumerable star sparkling foot hear lap lap ripple wave dark half shadowy figure stand right hand see distinguish form other lion be one sit back

paragraph: "Haddie," I exclaimed.
tokens: exclaim

paragraph: "Yes, yes, Geraldine, it's me," my brother's own dear voice replied. "We're going right over the sea--did you know?--isn't it splendid? We're going to see father and mamma. Hold out your hand so that you can feel mine."
tokens: brother own dear voice reply go sea know splendid go see father mamma hold hand feel

paragraph: [THE BROTHER LIONS ROSE INTO THE AIR.]
tokens: brother rose

paragraph: I did so, and my fingers clasped his, and at that moment the brother lions rose into the air, and down below, even fainter and fainter, came the murmur of the sea, while up above, the twinkling stars looked down on what surely was one of the strangest sights they had ever seen in all their long, long experience!
tokens: do finger clasp moment brother lion rise air fainter fainter come murmur sea twinkling star look strangest sight see long long experience

paragraph: Then again I seemed to know nothing, though somehow, all through, I felt the clasp of Haddie's hand and knew we were close together.
tokens: seem know feel clasp hand know close

paragraph: A beautiful light streaming down upon us, of which I was conscious even through my closed eyelids, was the next thing I remember. It seemed warm as well as bright, and I felt as if basking in it.
tokens: beautiful light stream conscious close eyelid next thing remember seem warm bright feel bask

paragraph: "Wake up, Geraldine," said Haddie's voice.
tokens: wake say voice

paragraph: I opened my eyes. But now I have come to a part of my story which I have never been able, and never shall be able, to put into fitting words. The scene before me was too beautiful, too magically exquisite for me even to succeed in giving the faintest idea of it. Still I must try, though knowing that I cannot but fail.
tokens: open eye come part story able able put fitting word scene beautiful exquisite succeed give faintest idea try know fail

paragraph: Can you picture to yourselves the loveliest day of all the perfect summer days you have ever known--no, more than that, a day like summer and spring in one--the richness of colour, the balmy fragrance of the prime of the year joined to the freshness, the indescribable hopefulness and expectation which is the charm of the spring? The beauty and delight seemed made up of everything lovely mingled together--sights, sounds, scents, feelings. There was the murmur of running streams, the singing of birds, the most delicious scent from the flowers growing in profusion and of every shade of colour.
tokens: picture loveliest day perfect summer day know more day summer spring richness colour balmy fragrance prime year join freshness indescribable hopefulness expectation charm spring beauty delight seem make lovely mingle sight sound scent feeling be murmur run stream singing bird delicious scent flower grow profusion shade colour

paragraph: Haddie and I looked at each other--we still held each other by the hand, but now, somehow, we were standing together on the grass, though I could not remember having got down from my perch on the lion's back.
tokens: look other hold other hand stand grass remember get perch lion back

paragraph: "Where are the lions, Haddie?" I said.
tokens: lion say

paragraph: Haddie seemed to understand everything better than I did.
tokens: seem understand good

paragraph: "They're all right," he replied, "resting a little. You see we've come a long way, Geraldine, and so quick."
tokens: right reply rest little see come long way quick

paragraph: "And where are we?" I asked. "What is this place, Haddie? Is it fairyland or--or--heaven?"
tokens: ask place fairyland heaven

paragraph: Haddie smiled.
tokens: smile

paragraph: "It's not either," he said. "You'll find out the name yourself. But come, we must be quick, for we can't stay very long. Hold my hand tight and then we can run faster."
tokens: say find name come quick stay long hold hand tight run fast

paragraph: I seemed to know that something more beautiful than anything we had seen yet was coming. I did not ask Haddie any more questions, even though I had a feeling that he knew more than I did. He seemed quite at home in this wonderful place, quite able to guide me. And his face was shining with happiness.
tokens: seem know beautiful see come ask more question have feeling know more seem home wonderful place able guide face shine happiness

paragraph: We ran a good way, and very fast. But I did not feel at all tired or breathless. My feet seemed to have wings, and all the time the garden around us grew lovelier and lovelier. If Haddie had not been holding my hand so fast I should scarcely have been able to resist stopping to gather some of the lovely flowers everywhere in such profusion, or to stand still to listen to the dear little birds singing so exquisitely overhead.
tokens: run good way feel tired breathless foot seem have wing time garden grow lovely lovely hold hand able resist stop gather lovely flower such profusion stand listen dear little bird sing

paragraph: "It must be fairyland," I repeated to myself more than once, in spite of what Haddie had said.

paragraph: But suddenly all thought of fairyland or flowers, birds and garden, went out of my head, as Haddie stopped in his running.
tokens: thought fairyland flower bird garden go head stop running

paragraph: "Geraldine," he half whispered, "look there."
tokens: half whisper look

paragraph: "There" was a little arbour a few yards from where we stood, and there, seated on a rustic bench, her dear face all sunshine, was mamma!
tokens: be little arbour few yard stand seat rustic bench dear face sunshine mamma

paragraph: She started up as soon as she saw us and hastened forward, her arms outstretched.
tokens: start see hasten arm outstretched

paragraph: "My darlings, my darlings," she said, as Haddie and I threw ourselves upon her.

paragraph: She did look so pretty; she was all in white, and she had a rose--one of the lovely roses I had been admiring as we ran--fastened to the front of her dress.

paragraph: "Mamma, mamma," I exclaimed, as I hugged her, "oh, mamma, I am so happy to be with you. Is this your garden, mamma, and may we stay with you always now? Wasn't it good of the lions to bring us? I have been so unhappy, mamma--somebody said you would get ill far away. But nobody could get ill here. Oh, mamma, you will let us stay always."

paragraph: She did not speak, but looking at Haddie I saw a change in his face.
tokens: speak look see change face

paragraph: "Geraldine," he said, "I told you we couldn't stay long. The lions would be scolded if we did, and you know you must say your French poetry."
tokens: say tell stay lion scold know say french poetry

paragraph: And then there came over me the most agonising feeling of disappointment and misery. All the pent-up wretchedness of the last weeks at school woke up and overwhelmed me like waves of dark water. It is as impossible for me to put this into words as it was for me to describe my exquisite happiness, for no words ever succeed in expressing the intense and extraordinary sensations of some dreams. And of course, as you will have found out by this time, the strange adventures I have been relating were those of a dream, though I still, after all the years that have passed since then, remember them so vividly.
tokens: come agonising feeling disappointment misery pent wretchedness last week school wake overwhelm wave dark water impossible put word describe exquisite happiness word succeed express intense extraordinary sensation dream course find time strange adventure relate dream year pass remember

paragraph: It was the fatal words "French poetry" that seemed to awake me--to bring back my terrible unhappiness, exaggerated by the fact of my dreaming.
tokens: fatal word french poetry seem awake bring terrible unhappiness exaggerate fact dreaming

paragraph: "French poetry," I gasped, "oh, Haddie, how can you remind me of it?"
tokens: french poetry gasp remind

paragraph: Haddie suddenly turned away, and I saw the face of one of the lions looking over his shoulder, with, strange to say, a white frilled cap surrounding it.
tokens: turn see face lion look shoulder strange say white frilled cap surround

paragraph: "You must try to drink this, my dear," said the lion, if the lion it was, for as I stared at him the brown face changed into a rather ruddy one--a round good-humoured face, with pleasant eyes and smile, reminding me of mamma's old nurse who had once come to see us.
tokens: try drink dear say lion lion stare brown face change ruddy one round good humoured face pleasant eye smile remind mamma old nurse come see

paragraph: I stared still more, and sat up a little, for, wonderful to relate, I was no longer in the lovely garden, no longer even in the show-room leaning against the lion: I was in bed in a strange room which I had never seen before. And leaning over me was the owner of the frilled cap, holding a glass in her hand.
tokens: stare more sit little wonderful relate lovely garden show room lean lion bed strange room see lean owner frilled cap hold glass hand

paragraph: "Try to drink this, my dearie," she said again, and then I knew it was not the lion but this stranger who had already spoken to me.
tokens: try drink dearie say know lion stranger speak

paragraph: I felt very tired, and I sank back again upon the pillow. What did it all mean? Where was I? Where had I been? I asked myself this in a vague sleepy sort of way, but I was too tired to say it aloud, and before I could make up my mind to try I fell asleep again.
tokens: feel tired sink pillow mean ask vague sleepy sort way tired say make mind try fall

paragraph: The room seemed lighter the next time I opened my eyes. It was in fact nearly the middle of the day, and a fine day--as clear as it ever was in Great Mexington. I felt much better and less tired now, almost quite well, except for a slight pain in my throat which told me I must have caught cold, as my colds generally began in my throat.
tokens: room seem light next time open eye fact middle day fine day clear great feel good tired slight pain throat tell catch cold cold begin throat

paragraph: "I wonder if it was with riding so far in the night," I first said to myself, with a confused remembrance of my wonderful dream. "I didn't feel at all cold on the lion's back, and in the garden it was lovelily warm."
tokens: wonder ride night say confuse remembrance wonderful dream feel cold lion back garden warm

paragraph: Then, as my waking senses quite returned, I started. It had been only a dream--oh dear, oh dear! But still, _something_ had happened--I was certainly not in my little bed in the corner of the room I shared with Emma and Harriet Smith at Green Bank. When had my dream begun, or was I still dreaming?
tokens: wake sense return start dream dear dear _something_ happen little bed corner room share green dream begin dreaming

paragraph: I raised myself a little, very softly, for now I began to remember the good-humoured face in the frilled cap, and I thought to myself that unless its owner were a dream too, perhaps she was still in the room, and I wanted to look about me first on my own account.
tokens: raise little begin remember good humoured face frilled cap think owner dream room want look own account

paragraph: What there was to see was very pleasant and very real. I felt quite sure I was not dreaming now, wherever I was. It was a large old-fashioned room, with red curtains at the two windows and handsome dark wood furniture. There was a fire burning cheerfully in the grate and the windows looked very clean, even though there was a prospect of chimney-tops to be seen out of the one nearest to me, which told me I was still in a town. And then I began to distinguish sounds outside, though here in this room it was so still. There were lots of wheels passing, some going quickly, some lumbering along with heavy slowness--it was much noisier than at Miss Ledbury's or at my own old home. Here I seemed to be in the very heart of a town. I began to recall the events of the day before more clearly. Yes, up to the time I remembered leaning against the carved lion in Mr. Cranston's show-room all had been real, I felt certain. I recollected with a little shiver the scene in the drawing-room at Green Bank, and how they had all refused to believe I was speaking the truth when I declared that the French poetry had entirely gone out of my head. And then there was the making up my mind that I could bear school no longer, and the secretly leaving the house, and at last losing my way in the streets.
tokens: be see pleasant real feel sure dreaming large old fashioned room red curtain window handsome dark wood furniture be fire burn grate window look clean be prospect chimney top see one near tell town begin distinguish sound room be lot wheel pass go lumber heavy slowness noisy own old home seem very heart town begin recall event day time remember lean carve lion show room real feel certain recollect little shiver scene draw room green refuse believe speak truth declare french poetry go head be making mind bear school leave house last lose way street

paragraph: I had meant to go to Mrs. Selwood's, or at least to get her address and write to her--but where was I now?--what should I do?
tokens: mean go least get address write do

paragraph: My head grew dizzy again with trying to think, and a faint miserable feeling came over me and I burst into tears.

paragraph: I did not cry loudly. But there was some one watching in the room who would have heard even a fainter sound than that of my sobs--some one sitting behind my bed-curtains whom I had not seen, who came forward now and leant over me, saying, in words and voice which seemed curiously familiar to me,
tokens: cry be one watch room hear fainter sound sob one sit bed curtain see come lean say word voice seem familiar

paragraph: "Geraldine, my poor little girl."
tokens: poor little girl
